section_purpose: This section introduces continuous relaxation methods for SAT solving, explaining how discrete Boolean problems are transformed into continuous optimization tasks to enable gradient-based techniques and provide approximation guarantees.
key_points: Continuous relaxations map Boolean variables to continuous domains, allowing gradient-based optimization for SAT problems.
The Fourier-SAT method uses Walsh-Fourier transform to convert Boolean formulas into multilinear polynomials for continuous optimization.
Semidefinite Programming (SDP) relaxation lifts variables to high-dimensional vector spaces, representing Boolean variables as unit vectors with an additional vector for 'true'.
SDP optimization maximizes clause satisfaction based on inner products between vectors, followed by rounding to discrete assignments.
This approach provides approximation guarantees, such as a 0.878 ratio for MAX-2-SAT, ensuring at least 87.8% of the maximum possible clauses are satisfied.

algorithms: Fourier-SAT method via Walsh-Fourier transform and polynomial optimization
SDP relaxation with vector initialization, optimization, and rounding
formulas: Boolean variables \(x_{i} \in \{0,1\}\) transformed to unit vectors \(\mathbf{y}_{i}\)
Clause satisfaction expressed as functions of inner products between vectors, e.g., with \(\mathbf{y}_{0}\) representing true

dependencies: Basic understanding of Boolean SAT and MaxSAT from section 3.1
Knowledge of continuous optimization techniques and approximation algorithms
reproducibility_notes: Detailed formulation of Walsh-Fourier transform for Fourier-SAT
Specific SDP relaxation setup for MAX-2-SAT or MAX-3-SAT
Rounding procedure based on sign of inner products with \(\mathbf{y}_{0}\)
